 - ii - facilities will be built. Pakistan's Social Action Programme (SAP), an important umbrella initiative supported by IDA and other donors, is addressing social sector problems nationally. The proposed four year project will complement the overarching SAP initiatives by focusing in detail on NA and AJK's health sectors. As the project will take a program approach, agreements are necessary between the Governments and IDA on the overall sectoral policies, on well developed sectoral programs and implementation plans, and on carefully designed monitoring procedures. IDA financing will be on a time-slice basis. The project aims to support the Governments in their effort to improve health status substantially and in particular to reduce infant and maternal mortality by about 30 percent. The project will help the two regions to: (a) improve quality and sustainability of primary health care especially through the development of community involvement and NGOs; (b) increase cost-effectiveness and coverage of Government health services; (c) strengthen human resources development especially for the critical female paramedical staff; and (d) build institutional capacity through better management and organizational development. With the rugged terrain, harsh weather and isolated settlements, a community based decentralized approach is central to the project design and the only way to provide sustainable services. To ensure organizational and financial sustainability, project components have been simplified as far as possible with a careful choice of the most cost-effective interventions. The community involvement emphasis would help to ensure sustainability. There will be one major annual review to check project progress on implementing the agreed policy and program measures, to ensure appropriate financing is available, and to monitor overall project implementation. The project will be implemented by the two Departments of Health and by cooperating NGOs and community organizations. Benefits and Risks: The main benefits will be improving the health of this very poor and under- served population, with a special emphasis on the needs of women and children who are presently particularly disadvantaged. Economic returns to investments targeted at women are high since improvements translate into the lives of those in her charge. It is estimated that by the end of the proposed project, over two million women and children will have benefitted from increased access to better quality primary health care. The project would lower fertility and hence population growth, through improved health status increase individuals' capacity as economic agents, improve health service use and cost-effectiveness, strengthen staff skills, and make service provision more efficient. The main risk is that the limited implementation capacity of the regions would be further strained by the complexity of the program approach and by introducing community involvement. This is addressed through including substantial management development and technical support, simplifying project components as far as possible, completing detailed preparation well in advance, and working with experienced NGOs as partners. A second risk is that the Government would fail in its commitment to finance the expanding programs at the agreed levels. The Government's record over the past three years in protecting social sector budgets from cuts is good. It has generally complied with its budgetary commitments to the social sectors. Failure to implement fully the proposed changes in health policy and thereby delay project implementation is a third risk. The program approach design mitigates this risk through having approved policy documents, annual agreements on specific reforms, and detailed work plans. The close association with SAP and the strengthened role of NGOs and communities provide further leverage. A fourth risk is that essential additional female staff would be unavailable. The proposed project includes specific measures to enlist women's organizations to help recruit staff, introduce incentives, provide culturally appropriate training and security, introduce incentives, and ensure women are posted to their home areas; experience so far is encouraging. Finally, any resurgence of ethnic or political strife in these regions would affect project implementation; there is little that can be done through the project to reduce such risks.

 ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF PAKISTAN NORTHERN HEALTH PROGRAM PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT I. Country and Sector Background A. Current Health Situation 1. Pakistan's economic performance in the past two decades has been relatively strong, with GDP growth averaging nearly 6 percent per year, although it has fallen to an annual average of 3.6 percent since 1993. The rapid annual population growth of 3 percent has severely restricted per capita consumption gains. Many years of neglect of the social sectors have put Pakistan among the group of developing countries with the worst social indicators and widest disparity between males and females in health, education, and earnings potential. Northern Pakistan, comprising the Northern Areas (NA) and Azad Jammu & Kashmir (AJK), is particularly disadvantaged and has received a very limited share of Pakistan's increased wealth. In these two regions, nearly four million people live scattered over a vast area of exceptionally rugged terrain. Poverty is pervasive and access to even the most basic services is extremely limited. Average annual per capita income in Pakistan is approximately Rs 10,300, but only about Rs 5,600 in NA and Rs 7,300 in AJK (1991 prices)1. About three years ago, the Government of Pakistan adopted a Social Action Programme (SAP) to begin to redress the neglect of basic social services. With assistance from donors including IDA, general support to programs under the SAP umbrella in primary education, primary health, family planning, and rural water and sanitation are now underway, as well as discrete investment projects in all four of Pakistan's provinces. However, barely any donor assistance for the social sectors, other than modest general support through SAP, has reached these two remote regions of NA and AJK. 2. The two regions share a similar pattem of disease, which differs somewhat from the national picture. Overall health status is lower in NA than in AJK. The incidence of acute respiratory infection (ARI) and tuberculosis (TB) is more than in Pakistan's four provinces, while diarrheal diseases are a major cause of death in the provinces and the two regions alike. Leprosy, not a problem in the provinces, is still a public health problem in both regions -- while for malaria, the position is reversed. Anemia is widespread among women of reproductive age in NA and AJK, due to high incidence of intestinal worms and poverty; iodine deficiency is endemic (affecting one-third of school children in NA). Due to primitive communications, rugged terrain, and severe weather conditions, emergency cases often cannot reach available services. Pakistan's maternal mortality ratio and fertility rate are high, but even worse in NA and AJK -- maternal mortality is estimated at 700 deaths per 100,000 live births and fertility is close to seven births per woman. Similarly, infant and child mortality, estimated to be 130 and 160 in NA and 90 and 130 in AJK respectively, are significantly above national levels. 3. Health care in NA and AJK is mainly provided by the Government; the role of non-government organizations (NGOs) is limited and that of the private commercial sector is very small. Primary health care and basic referral services, provided through a hierarchy of Government facilities, are weak and not effectively linked to communities. Higher referral service are provided by a few large hospitals in the main centers. Total public spending in the two regions for health is Rs 550 million in 1995/96, equivalent to Rs 162 per capita of which about 57 percent is for primary health (development and recurrent). About 76 percent of the total program budget is for recurrent expenditure. The Federal Govemment provides substantial support to NA and AJK. NA has autonomy to implement programs but is fully dependent financially on the Federal Government. The Chief Executive of NA is a member of the Pakistan Cabinet. 1 Punjab Economic Research Institute, 1992.
 AJK has autonomy in managing its affairs through its Parliament, but the Federal Government provides development grants and meets the budgetary deficit. (See also Institutional Assessment, Section III, Part B). B. Main Sector Issues 4. Years of neglect have left the health sector in a very primitive state. The current situation is due mainly to substantial deficiency in government budget allocations, especially for non-salary recurrent budgets. Overall budgets in NA and AJK have been declining for the past ten years and, as a result, non- salary recurrent health expenditure has been squeezed to unacceptably low levels. Rising expenditure on secondary health facilities has also led to cuts in primary health care spending (especially in AJK). Many existing facilities are functioning without the staff, medicine, equipment and space necessary for basic operations. In NA, about one-third of the buildings are 15-25 years old and 85 percent of all buildings have never been repaired or renovated. The injection of funds necessary to improve the quality of services would raise the public's confidence in the facilities, increase utilization, and make service provision more cost- effective. In AJK, given the adverse conditions, the health system is functioning relatively well. The strategy, therefore, is to build on the gains made through current efforts to develop the health sector. In both regions, the proposed Credit will finance a much needed and long overdue boost to both capital and recurrent expenditure that will bring the health services to a minimum level, especially in NA where the situation is worse. 5. Providing health services to a widely scattered population in rugged, mountainous terrain is relatively expensive on a per capita basis. Northern Pakistan is the apex of many of the highest mountain ranges in the world. Communications are poor and population density is very low, only about 15 persons per square kilometer. With a limited network of functioning health facilities, complications of pregnancy and accidents, as well as diseases such as pneumonia and TB, are major killers. Provision of even basic primary health and family planning services is significantly more difficult than in the rest of the country. The dearth of health services provided by the commercial private sector puts an added burden on Government services. But, the potential pay-off from providing preventive and basic services is correspondingly high. 6. The main public health needs -- reproductive and child health services -- are not being effectively addressed. Current provision of these services is very limited with little preventive and promotive care, almost non-existent outreach services, and poor referral services. In NA, where government services are the most deficient, part of the vacuum in primary health service provision has been filled by the Aga Khan Health Services (AKHS), an NGO that provides successful community-based services in two districts (20- 25 percent of the NA population); they rely on the public sector for referral facilities. Limited services are also provided by two NGOs: the Family Planning Association of Pakistan (FPAP) and the Marie Adelaide Foundation (MAF), which runs a very effective leprosy and TB control program. In AJK, only 15 percent of facilities are providing maternal and child health (MCH) services; the rest lack the space, staff, equipment and medicines required. FPAP and MAF are also active in AJK. 7. Lack of trained staff-- especially female -- is a major problem. Female patients can usually only be treated by female health staff. The limited number of female staff, especially Lady Health Visitors (LHVs), is a major constraint to improving the health of women and the children under their care. In NA, there are 64 LH`Vs working under the auspices of AKHS and only 14 for the government -- or I per 35,000 people. There are two gynecologists in all of NA. In AJK, the position is only marginally better. At the community level, the Government has recently initiated an effort to recruit female staff to provide basic health and family planning services and advice through the national Lady Health Workers (LHWs)

Institutional and management capacity is limited. Management at the headquarters and district level is weak, particularly in NA, and a proper system is needed to coordinate with NGOs and communities. In both regions, managers of the Government health services are very few and overworked. The current centralized system is not amenable to delivering services in these extreme conditions. In AJK, the current dual system of management, with significant military involvement in the provision of health services, makes administration inefficient. Furthermore, the staff (predominantly male) and drugs that the military provide are mismatched to a program with a strong maternal, child and community-based approach. In both regions, management reorganization is also needed to integrate immunization and communicable disease control services with other health services. Management information systems are underused and require strengthening. 9. Community involvement has been limited and needs to be expanded. Given the extremely adverse conditions, it is very difficult for any centralized system to function; it is essential that communities are involved in the management and provision of their own health care and fostering such participation is integral to the proposed project. Genuine community involvement improves service acceptability, cost- effectiveness, sustainability and quality of service provision. In NA, the Aga Khan Rural Support Program (AKRSP) has been successful in organizing general community involvement, while AJK has only very limited and recent community involvement experience. C. Sector Strategy 10. The Governments' strategies to address the above issues and to develop the sector is articulated in the 1995 NA and AJK Health Policy Statements (Annexes 6 and 7). The Statements were drafted and formally approved during project preparation. They incorporate a substantial reform agenda and, in contrast to earlier health policies, give genuine priority to primary health care and women's health. This is an important development; it is the first time that health sector policy for these regions has been documented. Similar documents have not generally been prepared elsewhere in Pakistan, nor are existing policies as strong in their emphasis on primary health care. The Statements were prepared separately by the twvo Governments but propose similar approaches. Recognizing the economic and social benefits that flow from improved health status, the overall goal is to improve the health status of the public, particularly mothers and children, by 30 percent in the next five years. The strategies are to strengthen the promotive and preventive components of health care, improve the quality of basic curative services, improve the overall performance of the Departments of Health (DOH) in each region, coordinate planning, management, and operations among government agencies, NGOs and communities, and provide more effective federal support to health operations and management in the two regions. As part of these strategies, MCH and family planning services specifically will be expanded and improved. The strategies call also for a lean but effective system of referral facilities, including essential obstetric care, staff development, and a more equitable distribution of services among areas. More broadly, the strategies emphasize decentralized management, using NGOs to facilitate community involvement in the planning and provision of care, but recognize the likely modest role of the private commercial sector. They call for increased total expenditure on public health to redress past neglect and resolution of the chronic non-salary recurrent budget problems. The strategies emphasize bringing existing facilities up to minimum operating standards through investments over a limited time, with very limited construction of new facilities. IDA endorses this focus on primary health care, supported by obstetric and other emergency referral care, as well as increased involvement of NGOs and the community, as a cost-effective way to address health needs in NA and AJK. This approach is consistent with, and supportive of, the overall SAP strategy.
 - 4 - II. The Project A. Program/Project Approach 11. A "program" approach will be followed, similar to that adopted in the recent Pakistan SAP2 and Population Welfare Program3 Projects. This approach requires an agreement between the Governments and IDA on the overall sectoral policies and strategies, including directions for reform, during the next four to five years, well developed programs of activities and implementation plans, and carefully designed monitoring and evaluation schemes. The proposed project will operate under the umbrella of the national SAP, with the detailed project work in each region contributing to the development of the broad SAP annual plans. SAP conditionality, financing and disbursements will be complementary to those for the project. The program activities, implementation plans, progress indicators, and budgets for NA and AJK, both development and recurrent, have been developed within the framework of the Health Policy Statements, and have been agreed between the Governments and IDA. Each year, progress made during the previous year will be reviewed, and the health sector program for the coming financial year (both in budgetary terms and in content, plus the specifics of the reform measures to be implemented) will be defined in detail. IDA would need to have seen adequate progress during the previous year, ensure compliance with any overarching SAP agreements and approve each annual plan before releasing project funds for that year. With this approach, the Governments will have more flexibility in implementing the program than with the traditional project approach, but they will be responsible for meeting performance targets in order to receive annual funding. 12. The program comprises the total activities of the government health sector in NA and AJK plus eligible health-related activities with communities and NGOs, for the four years 1996/97 to 1999/2000. During project preparation it became clear that there were a number of large approved development schemes especially in AJK which could not be accommodated within the projected staffing and financial resources for the next four years. These were almost all for hospital development and therefore of a lower priority within the new health policies. The Governments agreed to scale down or defer such schemes. They also agreed that no new referral facilities would be built without prior consultation with IDA. These agreements will be carefully monitored through the annual review process. 13. Within the agreed programs, the proposed project comprises all incremental aspects of primary health in NA and AJK plus the critical supporting parts of the first referral level of accident, emergency and obstetric care. Activities in these areas will be financed on a time-slice basis by IDA while cooperating donors will finance conventionally. Details of the project are included in various Government project documents, and particularly in the project PC-ls. Development projects in Pakistan must be presented to the approving Government authorities in a prescribed detailed format, known as a PC-I. 14. The policy agenda for the four years, as included in the two Health Policy Statements, is outlined above and represents a very substantial shift toward giving primary health care and especially MCH true priority in the allocation of sectoral resources, in taking steps to ensure the availability of trained staff and supplies for rural facilities, in developing genuine community and NGO involvement in primary services, and in improving and decentralizing management. B. Project Objectives 15. The goal of the proposed project is to support the Governments' programs in NA and AJK to improve the health status of the population throughout all districts, with a specific target of reducing infant and maternal mortality by about 30 percent over the four years. Achieving this goal would also require reduced fertility. With a targeted, time-limited investment largely to improve existing services, a functioning system would be put in place to deliver a minimum set of cost-effective health services. Improved health status would result from achieving four objectives: (a) improving quality and sustainability of primary health care, including preventive measures, especially through the development of community involvement and NGOs; (b) increasing cost-effectiveness and coverage of Government health and family planning services, particularly through strengthening nearly 500 DOH health facilities including the basic referral level; (c) strengthening the capacity of the health sector through human resources development, including training over 600 female staff, and (d) building institutional capacity through better management and organizational development. 16. Annex 3 presents the operational targets within these four objectives and the performance indicators that will be used to monitor progress. Operational targets for the four objectives include: (a) increasing village and women's organizations such that the number of facilities with active community participation increases by 10 percent per annum; (b) fully staffing and equipping 320 facilities in AJK and 230 facilities in NA; (c) training 230 LHVs in AJK and 100 in NA, 200 female nursing assistants in AJK and 100 in NA and 200 paramedics in AJK and 100 in NA; and (d) providing in-service management training to about 150 staff in NA and 650 staff in AJK. C. Project Description 17. The proposed project will comprise four main components: (a) strengthening community and NGO participation; (b) strengthening Government health services; (c) human resource development; and (d) management and organizational development. 18. Strengthening Community and NGO Participation (US$12.2 million equivalent estimated base cost, 22 percent ofproject cost) Fostering the genuine involvement of communities in their health services would be a major contribution towards the combined objectives of improved quality and acceptability of services, cost-effectiveness, and sustainable health improvement. To date, community involvement in health services has been largely confined to NGO-run activities, particularly in two districts of NA. By its nature, the details of this component will evolve during project implementation, but the aim is to introduce community participation to most of the regions' existing health services by the end of the project. This would be achieved through a combination of: (a) strengthening and expanding existing NGO services; (b) adding new NGO services; and (c) introducing community and NGO involvement to existing Government
 -6 - services. The personnel of the larger established NGOs will participate as appropriate in the human resources and management development project components (see paras. 27 and 29). NGOs are more developed in NA than in AJK. In NA, where there is a tradition of NGO-Government cooperation, the proposed project will support: (a) strengthening and expanding the successful and pioneering community- oriented primary health model of the AKHS in the two districts where it presently operates plus experimenting with new initiatives and increasing Government-AKHS cooperation and service rationalization in those districts; (b) through the extensive network of AKRSP-developed community and women's organizations, introducing community concepts to existing Government primary health services in the remaining three districts of NA with technical advice, social mobilization, training and supervision provided by AKHS, AKRSP and associated NGOs; and (c) strengthening and expanding the existing and effective programs of the FPAP and MAF such that good quality family planning and leprosy/TB community-oriented services will be generally available, typically working from Government health facilities throughout NA. 19. In AJK, where there are long-standing informal partnerships between communities and government but few established NGOs, the project will build on these partnerships and support: (a) the establishment of an autonomous Social Mobilization Unit (SMU), representing communities, NGOs and the DOH, with teams in each district to plan, coordinate, implement, and supervise the introduction of community involvement in existing primary health services, which are largely Government-run; and (b) the strengthening and expansion of the existing programs of the FPAP and MAF (as in NA). Government has formalized involvement of the main NGOs in NA and AJK through a signed memoranda of understanding for each. 20. While the details will vary depending on locally determined needs, in both NA and AJK it is expected that the focus of the community services will be on MCH preventive and curative services provided by a paid facility-based LHV supported by a network of community-based workers or LHWs and traditional birth attendants (TBAs). Through a system of local and district committees (see "Project Implementation" below) communities will help: (a) plan the types and levels of services to be provided; (b) manage, supervise, and monitor provision of these services; (c) contribute to service financing (through land, buildings, volunteers, or cash as appropriate) and monitor expenditure; and (d) provide feedback to the district level. Local groups may be male, female, or mixed depending on local circumstances, but coordination between these groups will be important. As has already happened on a small scale in NA, it is expected that some local groups would evolve so that they could take over management of their local government facilities. Similarly, experience has shown that it is feasible to introduce a system of modest fees to recoup part of the medicine and consultation costs provided that the quality of services is maintained. Also, the project will experiment with the endowment fund concept (based on the SAP Community School Program) to help finance operations and maintenance of health facilities. The local adaptation of these financing and delivery models will vary, in accordance with the community's demand for health services, ability to pay, and management experience. 21. In NA and AJK, the communities will be involved in addressing the problem of insufficient female staff. Communities will be asked to nominate TBAs and qualified women for training as LHWs. After training, they will be linked to the health facility in their community. Similarly, after training, LHVs will be posted to facilities in their home areas and would only be transferred by mutual agreement and after review by a senior level committee. 22. Finally, to strengthen and support smaller NGOs in building community organizations and providing health and family planning services, an NGO fund will be created. The fund will be managed by

Strengthening Government Health Services. (US$29.0 million equivalent estimated base cost; 52 percent of project cost) The objective of the proposed project component is to improve the quality and coverage of Government health services, with particular attention to improving and expanding services for women and children, through an intensive one-time effort to upgrade existing facilities and services to a fully operational but basic level. The focus will be on upgrading and includes posting additional LHVs, providing working space, equipment and accommodation where deficiencies exist, and generally strengthening MCH and family planning services at health facilities. Communicable disease control programs will be strengthened and integrated more fully with other public health activities. Nutrition advice -- and health education generally -- and micronutrient supplements will be included in pre- and post-natal care and child health services. 24. With respect to infrastructure development, the proposed project will bring all existing primary facilities up to a minimum standard by the end of the project period. A detailed mapping exercise will be conducted to assess the adequacy of health facilities relative to the population distribution. Primary care facilities without MCH service space (165 facilities) will be expanded. For the few cases of new construction, land is available for almost all sites and procurement of the balance has been initiated. In addition to ensuring that all primary level health facilities are minimally equipped, supplied and functioning, the project will provide essential equipment and communications systems to higher level health facilities (at the district level and below) in order to strengthen the referral system. At the referral level, the emphasis will be on upgrading capacity to treat emergency cases, especially women with pregnancy complications, critically ill children and serious accidents. With the rugged terrain, improved transport and communications are essential; vehicles, including ambulances and motorcycles, will be provided to facilitate emergency transport, supervision, logistical support and outreach. 25. Provision of health education will be strengthened through reorganization of the present system and through increased activities and training. A position to coordinate health education activities will be created in each District Health Office and a local program pursued. Additionally, all levels of health personnel will be trained in health education and provided with materials. 26. The proposed project will assist in phasing out the military's support to the DOHs. Apart from replacing senior and middle level staff as trained civilians become available in NA and AJK, the cost of medicines currently being supplied by the military for AJK will be phased into the DOH recurrent budget. 27. Emphasis will be placed on increasing the number of female providers including LHVs and community-based workers trained in MCH and family planning. doc.abstracts: The goal of the Northern Health Program Project is to support the government's programs in Northern areas and Azad Jammu & Kashmir to improve the health status of the population throughout all districts, with a specific target of reducing infant and maternal mortality by about 30 percent over a four year period. Improved health status will result from achieving the following four objectives: 1) improving quality and sustainability of primary health care, including preventive measures; 2) increasing cost-effectiveness and coverage of government health and family planning services; 3) strengthening the capacity of the health sector; and 4) building institutional capacity. The project will comprise four main components: 1) strengthening of community and nongovernmental organization participation; 2) strengthening government health services; 3) human resource development; and 4) management and organizational development.
